column1: Title: State Funding of Abortions Under Medicaid | The Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation

column2: Follows Federal Standard, Funding Only Cases Involving Life Endangerment, Rape and Incest
column3: Funds All or Most Medically Necessary Abortions, Exceeding Federal Requirements

column1: The federal Hyde Amendment, passed in 1977, bans state use of federal Medicaid dollars to pay for abortions unless the pregnancy is the result of rape or incest, or the abortion is "necessary to save the life of the woman." States can use their own funds to cover other medically necessary abortions - usually defined by states as those to protect the physical or mental health of the woman - for Medicaid beneficiaries.
Guttmacher Institute, State Policies in Brief, "[State Funding of Abortion Under Medicaid](http://www.guttmacher.org/statecenter/spibs/spib_SFAM.pdf)," as of November 16, 2018.
1. A law that defines medically necessary is temporarily blocked by a court.
2. Despite a court order, the state Medicaid program does not pay for medically necessary abortions.
3. State also provides state funds for abortions that are necessary to prevent grave, long-lasting damage to the woman’s physical health.
4. Iowa governor must approve any abortion paid for by the Medicaid program.
5. State also provides state funds for abortions in cases of fetal impairment.
6. State only pays for abortions when necessary to protect the woman's life.
